Award.AwardTitle: Cosmic Ray Ion and Electron Production at Relativistic Shocks in Gamma-Ray Bursts
Award.AbstractNarration:
Gamma-Ray Bursts (GRBs) are fascinating and enigmatic objects in the
Universe. Ultra-High Energy Cosmic Rays (UHECR) have similarly caught the attention of physicists and astrophysicists, leading to, among other ideas, postulates of exotic origin based on predictions from particle physics. To make clearer a possible connection between UHECRs and GRBs, one needs to refine our understanding of how the cosmic ray spectrum couples to burst gamma-ray emission. Forging a more robust model of this connection is a principal goal of this proposal. The mandate to do so has been enhanced by the recent confirmation of the existence of the Greisen-Zatsepin-Kuzmin (GZK) cutoff in the UHECR spectrum at around 6 Â°? 1019 eV by the Pierre Auger experiment. This project will address how does the relativistic nature of the shocked outflow in bursts influence the prompt emission spectra that was detected in the gamma-ray band. A second question that will be addressed is what is the relative efficiency of accelerating electrons and ions in relativistic shocks thought to be present in GRBs, and how can photon data from these sources be used to probe this efficiency ratio,. Two other questions that will be investigated are whether GRB shocks efficiently generate ion populations up to the extremely high UHECR energies, and what are the anticipated neutrino fluxes from GRBs as potential signals for the IceCube experiment? The broader impacts are that the results will be adapted for display on publicly maintained Web sites. A graduate student will be engaged as an integral part of the work and this student will be involved in teaching at least two lectures per year on gamma-ray bursts in appropriate ndergraduate Rice courses. A long term goal of the PI is to develop a summer course at Rice offered to senior undergraduates including the topic of gamma-ray bursts. The PI plans to present aspects of this work, and highlights of the exciting field of gamma-ray bursts, to the general public and Houston area schools,continuing an established relationship with the Houston area astronomy societies and K-12 programs

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed a study of the nature and efficiency of the acceleration of energetic (relativistic) charged particles in gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) and blazars.  Gamma-Ray Bursts are among the most fascinating and enigmatic objects in the universe, captivating astrophysicists for over 3 decades now. They are the incipient remnants of the supernova explosions of massive stars, or perhaps the chaotic result of the merger of solar mass type black holes and neutron stars. Their blasts are so powerful that they eject collimated flows that move very close to the speed of light.  These flows are structured and contain shock waves, plasma discontinuities that energize electrons and protons.  These energetic particles moving at speeds incredibly close to the speed of light, emit X-rays and gamma-rays in prompt radiative outbursts, and these are detected by different satellite experiments, such as NASA's Fermi Gamma-Ray Space Telescope, and Swift Telescope.

Several outstanding questions pertaining to GRBs are at the forefront of scientific interest at the moment. Among these, this project provided insights into (i) how does the relativistic nature of the shocked outflow in bursts influence the prompt emission spectra that are detected in the gamma-ray band, (ii) what is the relative efficiency of accelerating electrons and ions in relativistic shocks thought to be present in GRBs, and (iii) how can photon data from these sources be used to probe this efficiency ratio.
Our analysis employed new developments of a well-tested Monte Carlo simulation of charges propagating and diffusing in the chaotic, magnetized environs of relativistic shocks in GRB plasma outflows. Simulation results assessed a variety of magnetic turbulence levels and mean magnetic field orientations in a shock neighborhood, and found that the probability distribution functions of electrons and ions had power-law slopes that sensitively depend on these magnetic properties.  These slopes are what connect to the gamma-ray data we see in GRBs; they also apply to relativistic jets outside a class of supermassive black holes in distant galaxies, called blazars. We discerned that a wide range of spectral slopes was possible, and that really fast plasma flows with only very modest turbulence generated steeper distributions with far fewer charges possessing the highest energies. An interesting regime of flat spectrum generation was identified, where charges are accelerated in asymmetric plasma electric fields straddling shock discontinuities.
The influence of these electric fields was probed at a deeper level for shocks that are thredded by light electrons and heavy protons (nuclei). The different masses of these species forces them to respond to magnetic and electric fields differently, and spatially separate near a shock, thereby generating stronger electric fields. Computing the response of the charges to these electric fields is non-trivial, and the students developed polished simulations for self-consistently analyzing this problem.   The net effect we determined is that energy is exchanged between charges of different masses, with the electrons being heated, and the protons being cooled.  The sense of this approach to energy equilibration is dictated by the ions possessing the majority of the incoming kinetic energy when the relativistic plasma flows into a shock. The Monte Carlo simulation determined this to be a strong modification to shock environments, with the result that there was a pronounced adjustment in the power-law population numbers of the electrons and ions: relativistic electrons are more numerous than previously thought. This improvement in efficiency argues more strongly in favor of the hypothesis that electrons are what is radiating the light we see in gamma-ray bursts and blazars.
